description: bowl form with rounded bottom with small flat foot; very wide, square rim; small bowl; striped designs of predominately orange, blue and yellow; some cloudy stripes running perpendicular to bright colored stripes
marks: Signture and Title at edge of rim on top surface, incised: [Klaus Moj
medium: Fused, slumped, manipulated and wheel ground mosaic glass
text: Glass fusing is now very popular, but Moje helped revive mosaic glass, or murrine, through fusing on a large, painterly scale decades ago. He concentrated on shallow dish forms or square panels with vivid juxtapositions of color, taking kiln-fused glass to another, bolder level. This shallow dish exploits his loose approach with saturated secondary and primary colors on a dark ground spilling off the plate like paint thrown on a canvas. He has influenced several younger generations of artists working with this technique, as founding director and instructor at the Glass Workshop, Canberra School of Art in Canberra, Australia.
